title: How to shop for a monitor that will work with your laptop - Quora

response.answer_text: Determine your needs and budget.Determine your laptop’s output options.Browse your choice of shops for monitors that fit your need and budget.To determine your needs, look at what you are using it for. Some monitors have better color quality for graphic design, some have higher resolutions for more workspace, others may have higher refresh rates for gaming. There are several good resources for figuring what kind of monitor you really want, but here is a link that will provide some information to help you with #1. LCD Panel Types Explored Once you have determined what kind of monitor you want, try to find one that will plug into your laptop. Keep in mind there are many adapters out there to convert the signal from one output to another. The output options could be one of the following:  Once you have determined the correct video output option you have available, take a look at various retailers like Amazon.com, Ebay.com, Newegg.com, TigerDirect.com, etc. for good deals. Take a look at the clearance, flash sales, rebates, etc. Make sure to check out their reviews as well. Some monitors may not fit your needs based on a factor that one specific review points out. An example would be a gamer looking for a monitor finds a killer deal on a monitor but finds that it’s 60hz. Most PC gamers would opt for a 120+hz monitor as it makes a big difference. If you have an issue with glare in the room the monitor will be you may not want a glossy finish on the screen. These kinds of things are personal preference. See if any brick & mortar stores have monitors in stock and see if you can eye any differences in that various types! Good luck!

Thanks for A2A. As I’ve yet to own a laptop that has anything other than DSub-15 video output, I’ve never had an issue connecting any monitor that accepts this as an input. Most new monitors on the market these days are going to be FHD (1920) or True-2k (2048) and finding something in 4:3 instead of 16:9 is going to be extremely difficult. Certainly you would have to do some research on the graphic capability of the specific laptop before hitting the markets. If it supports HDMI output, you may find that it can’t handle anything greater than True-2k so purchasing a UHD (3940) or True-4k (4096) could be a complete waste of money. If you’re looking at a higher-end budget, are you considering OLED technology or sticking with traditional LCD? If you want wider viewing angles, consider making sure that the LCD falls into the IPS category. Apart from those technical issues, you also need to look at the physical size of the display which will probably be 23+ inch in measurement to decide if it’s going to fit in your planned user space. Will you have to purchase a wall or deskmount VESA bracket to be able to use it? Is it flat shiny glass or matte finish that reduces glare? If you can’t find a matte display will you need to re-arrange your lighting to prevent glare? Personally, I prefer the matte screens but these are going out of favor by manufacturers.
